results.title: Remnants of Eden
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the possibility that this generation may preside over a biological mass extinction of half the species on earth today. It addresses the delicate balance of protecting life’s diversity whilst managing the needs of growing human populations. Examples are taken from Kenya, United States, Thailand, Oman and Costa Rica. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McCullough, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: In the name of progress
results.creator_credit: Katherine Carpenter, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines well-intended development projects in the third world and the environmental disasters that resulted, and questions whether environmental protection and economic development are inherently in conflict. It profiles ‘sustainable development’ alternatives in Brazil and India. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Do we really want to live this way?
results.creator_credit: Marty Ostrow, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the pollution problems associated with the world’s most affluent societies and includes case studies of air quality in Los Angeles and water quality in the Rhine River Basin. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Only One Atmosphere
results.creator_credit: Andrew Liebman, John Angier, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the new understanding of how human activities are altering the earth’s atmosphere. It explores damage to the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect, noting the probable consequences of these changes, and concludes by considering how societies can respond. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The Environmental revolution
results.creator_credit: Carol Lynn Dornbrand, John Angier, Chedd-Angier Productions, Film Australia and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This introductory episode examines the two major revolutions that have changed how human societies use resources - the agricultural and industrial revolutions. It then suggests that a third revolution - a global awareness of human impacts - is beginning to cause equally far-reaching changes in society. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The Enemy within (2003) [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Eva Colmers, Bonnie Thompson, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In World War II thousands of German prisoners-of-war were sent to camps in Canada where they saw out the war, many for several years. This documentary examines the experiences of a few of those men, as well as presenting the perspectives of the Canadian guards. Filmmaker Eva Colmers (a German-born resident of Canada) focuses on the story of her father - a POW who has fond memories of his time in captivity. If this seems disingenuous, it is through a series of interviews that he reveals that he was well fed, well treated and educated during his confinement. Of interest here is also the workings of a POW camp — how the men strictly adhered to their rank and values as soldiers, even remaining loyal to Hitler. What is clear is that they were treated with respect that fostered loyalty, to the point where the prisoners were released to work on farms, and as lumberjacks, and were even allowed at times, to wander beyond the barbwire. Overall this is a fascinating tale that mixes interviews with archival footage, thus presenting a very humanistic slant on what was a cruel and murderous time in history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eva Colmers, Bonnie Thompson, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Elizabeth R.
results.brief_description: Glenda Jackson received world-wide acclaim for her brilliant portrayal of Queen Elizabeth the Ist. The series begins just prior to Elizabeth’s ascension to the throne and continues to her death in 1603. The episodes deal with historical events such as the Armada, Mary Queen of Scots, the beheading of Essex, the plight over the Succession and her decision to remain unmarried. The series is well scripted, costumed and has an excellent cast.

results.title: The End of the game
results.creator_credit: Robin Lehman, Claire Wilbur and Opus Films
results.brief_description: In the African dawn, thunderclouds gather, welcomed by croaking frogs in the marshes. Monkeys swing on trees, lion cubs pull one another’s tails and the gnu, antelope and giraffe suckle their young. The animals of the savanna hunt and play. The sound of a rifle shatters the magic. Animals disappear - one by one - in a dramatic climax that makes a poignant plea for conservation. Filmed, without spoken commentary, by Robin Lehman in Kenya, Tanzania and Zaire.

results.title: The Enchanted Cottage
results.creator_credit: John Cromwell, Harriet Parsons and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A disfigured World War II veteran marries a decidedly plain girl and they seclude themselves inside a small New England cottage. A small miracle occurs when they are transformed into a handsome couple, as they see each other through the eyes of love. Based on the play by Sir Arthur Wing Pinero, this fable proves that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Starring Dorothy McGuire and Robert Young.

results.title: The Emu and the sun
results.brief_description: An animated film based on an Aboriginal legend about how emus became wingless birds and how sunlight came to earth.
